author: tersec
content:
I'll ask here, I guess -- one point I'd like to see clarified as well, maybe it's just my misunderstanding, but is the claim closer to:
- blob space is filling up, and it's constraining growth of L2's and other blob users, and it would be better for Ethereum if this constraint were lifted, but it's a gradual process either way, and such growth just somewhat slows or stalls for a while, until blob space is increased (by any means, deliberately leaving aside the specific mechanism(s)); or
- it's more akin to the over-staking concerns people bring up, where there's a mechanism where Ethereum without sufficiently increased blob space flips into a stable but undesireable equilibrium difficult to escape, where resuming growth of blob usage is actively more difficult than it would be if it'd been continued sooner?

author: potuz
content: We were told that moving to POS was delayed multiple times because one of the golden goals of Ethereum was that not only would you be able to validate the chain with your home computer, but you'd also be able to sequence/stake on it. For a while after the merge we could, and with "pretend ETH" (since it wasn't even clear that it could eventually go out) we would fight with Ben Edington on wether Prysm or Teku included more attestations. By the time of the merge, even before it, when the beacon chain was actually going to stop being pretend ETH and be for real, we were told that you could still sequence the chain with your home computer, but you'd be better off sending blocks to sorcerers in the Dark Forest, these would cast spells and with magic reordering of transactions would get more value to your block. You can't compete with them cause they have transactions that your node won't even see... we were so told. Still some preferred to stick to their own building and trust that their local execution engine will pack the best transactions they could, in as much as they could from their local mempool so that they'd get their most profitable, censor free block out there. We are now turning yet another page and we are saying that we can't even fill our blocks in our home computers. That we have to leave some space out. At this point I ask: is this or is it not an admission that we have entrusted thus external, off-protocol, trusted entities, to fill our blocks? We are thinking on providing flags to users that can no longer fill their blocks to submit a second tier kind of block up to the network. To distort the effects of 1559 that may even lower the gas price of the next block thinking that the network is not in demand. We are allowing home stakers to not include a perfectly valid tx that paid enough fees. Two days ago this would be called clearly censoring. Now it's saving the homestakers? So I repeat, if we are in a position in which we are admitting to needing

author: potuz
content: to outsource production to trusted off-protocol entities that have the means to actually fill the blockspace, why aren't we putting these entities in-protocol?

author: terencechain
content: Timing for proposal is tricky. How long is the timeout? Is the timeout coming from Teku or mev-boost? Does the relayer play a timing game there? If you timeout at the 3-second mark and then decide to use the local block, blocks can easily get orphaned, and this is independent of blobs. If you timeout at the 2-second mark, then it's probably fine. It depends on when you call `GetHeader`...

author: francis.li
content:
I believe there are two main reasons:
1. Increasing demand: both base (10 -> 25 Mgas/s) and op (initial increase to 7.5Mgas/s) are planning to increase throughput in the next few months, and with the planned increase, current blob capacity will be exceeded soon
2. As Vatalik mentioned here (https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1153#issuecomment-2377002932), not only does the lack of extra blob space constrain existing rollups, it also stops new rollups that considered blobs but decided not to and moved to alt DA solutions.

author: tersec
content: Ok, point (2) in particular does help address this question.

author: robocopsgonemad
content: one aspect of this that has become clearer to me, is that the bandwidth constraint is very different than other resource constraints. Access to quality, commodity hardware is way easier to come by than access to quality infrastucture.  All things being equal, if I can trade bandwidth requirements for hardware requirements, i'll do it every time.

author: jochembrouwer
content:
Yes, this is an exactly good point and also one which I realized today. Getting more beefier hardware is much easier than getting a better connection. Especially in the sense of "home staking" where we really mean "at home", it is almost impossible to get a better connection, the only alternative is to move your node out-of-house and to a dedicated location with a good connection. (Slight side node: I do not support that the protocol needs extreme beefy hardware to validate, but I am assuming that this is the general consensus).

So, this means (and this is already being done on devnets) that not only performance benchmarks are a thing, but also the bandwidth consumption. I realized that this has been tested a lot in the past, but it is actually at this point I completely realize the importance of the bandwidth requirements üôÇ
